title.value: Distinctive Whole-brain Cell-Types Strongly Predict Tissue Damage Patterns in Eleven Neurodegenerative Disorders
title.justification: The title of the paper as provided at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Distinctive Whole-brain Cell-Types Strongly Predict Tissue Damage Patterns in Eleven Neurodegenerative Disorders

extractions.description: This paper investigates the association between distinct whole-brain cell-types and tissue damage patterns in eleven neurodegenerative disorders. The study utilizes data integration from spatial gene expression, structural MRI, and cell deconvolution to create comprehensive maps of cellular abundance and analyze their overlap with brain atrophy patterns in diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

type.justification: The paper involves experimental data collection and analysis, including the construction of whole-brain reference maps using structural MRI, gene expression data, and cell deconvolution techniques.
type.quote: By unifying spatial gene expression, structural MRI, and cell deconvolution, here we describe how the human brain distribution of canonical cell-types extensively predicts tissue damage in eleven neurodegenerative disorders, including early- and late-onset Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, dementia with Lewy bodies, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, frontotemporal dementia, and tauopathies.

name.justification: The study focuses on neurodegenerative diseases, brain cell-types, and their association with tissue damage, which are central themes in the field of Neuroscience.
name.quote: Our results support the strong mediating role of non-neuronal cells, primarily microglia and astrocytes, on spatial vulnerability to tissue loss in neurodegeneration, with distinct and shared across-disorders pathomechanisms.

name.justification: The study is centered on understanding the patterns of tissue damage in various neurodegenerative diseases.
name.quote: We obtained whole-brain voxel-wise atrophy maps for eleven neurodegenerative conditions, including early- and late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (EOAD and LOAD, respectively), Parkinson’s disease (PD), amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), frontotemporal dementia (FTD), dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) and dementia-related pathologies (presenilin-1, TDP43A, TDP43C, 3RTau, and 4RTau; see Materials and Methods, Disease-specific atrophy maps subsection)32, 33.

name.justification: The paper utilizes imaging transcriptomics to map gene expression to brain structures and associate these with neurodegenerative disease patterns.
name.quote: By unifying spatial gene expression, structural MRI, and cell deconvolution, here we describe how the human brain distribution of canonical cell-types extensively predicts tissue damage in eleven neurodegenerative disorders.

name.justification: The Brain Cell-type Specific Gene Expression Analysis (BRETIGEA) software was used to estimate cell-type proportions from bulk RNA.
name.quote: Next, at each GM location, densities for multiple canonical cell-types were estimated using the Brain Cell-type Specific Gene Expression Analysis software (BRETIGEA)41. This deconvolution method41 accurately estimates cell proportions from bulk mRNA for six major cell-types

aliases: Brain Cell-type Specific Gene Expression Analysis

is_contributed.justification: BRETIGEA was used in the study but not developed as part of this research.
is_contributed.quote: This deconvolution method41 accurately estimates cell proportions from bulk mRNA for six major cell-types

is_executed.justification: The model was executed as part of the study to generate cell-type proportion data.
is_executed.quote: Next, at each GM location, densities for multiple canonical cell-types were estimated using the Brain Cell-type Specific Gene Expression Analysis software (BRETIGEA)41.

is_compared.justification: The model is used as a tool and not compared numerically with other models in the paper.
is_compared.quote: Next, at each GM location, densities for multiple canonical cell-types were estimated using the Brain Cell-type Specific Gene Expression Analysis software (BRETIGEA)41.

referenced_paper_title.value: Brain Cell Type Specific Gene Expression and Co-expression Network Architectures
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the referenced paper where BRETIGEA is detailed.
referenced_paper_title.quote: This deconvolution method41 accurately estimates cell proportions from bulk mRNA for six major cell-types

name.justification: The AHBA provided transcriptomic data used for mapping gene expression in the study.
name.quote: In addition, we obtained bulk transcriptomic data for the adult human brain from the Allen Human Brain Atlas (AHBA)39. This included high-resolution coverage of nearly the entire brain, measuring expression levels for over 20,000 genes from 3702 distinct tissue samples of six post-mortem specimens, and detailed structural MRI data (see Materials and Methods, Mapping gene expression data) 39.

referenced_paper_title.value: The Allen Human Brain Atlas: comprehensive gene expression mapping of the human brain
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper that describes the AHBA dataset in detail.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The AHBA included anatomical and histological data collected from six healthy human specimens with no known neurological disease history (one female; age range 24–57 years; mean age 42.5 ± 13.38 years)39.

name.justification: PPMI data was utilized for constructing atrophy maps for Parkinson’s disease cases.
name.quote: The PPMI is a multi-center international study with approved protocols by the local institutional review boards at all 24 sites across the US, Europe, and Australia83. MRI and clinical data used in constructing atrophy maps were collected from 232 participants with PD83.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper that describes the PPMI dataset in detail.
referenced_paper_title.quote: MRI data for PD, consisted of 3T high-resolution T1-weighted scans, were obtained from the Parkinson’s Progression Markers Initiative (PPMI) database (www.ppmiinfo.org/data).

name.justification: MATLAB was used for hierarchical clustering analyses and data visualization.
name.quote: Hierarchical clustering analyses was applied using in-built MATLAB function for data visualization.
